data.text: it's pretty old. Ot came from the factory that way.i also have a world troller with SS COUPLERS. i bought it from a surly dealership and it came that way for $1200. All this was 10 years ago
data.author: Larry Morgan

data.text: Ahhh... that was the LHT Deluxe, I think it was called. I always wanted one of those, but they stopped making them before I was aware of them.
data.author: Tim Bessie

data.text: yes,LHT Deluxe. I bought it on Ebay. I flew it to Kathmandu Nepal and rode into India. Then I got excited and bought the world troller and built it up really nice I was going bike touring but I like hiking in the Himalayas more because it is quiet. I didn't like all the dangerous cars in Asia.
data.author: Larry Morgan

data.text: Yeah, that would be a worry for me in these more far-flung locales. I've been cycling mostly on the California coast (I live in SF) and in Europe/UK since I started doing tours. A lot safer feeling. So many little country roads in Europe, it's a real pleasure deciding which route I want to take, what I'll see, etc.

data.author: Paul Nicholas Woollams

data.text: Any bike that is my size, that has gears, that has a comfortable seat, positioned correctly . I began in California feb 2 arrived in Warwick New York. April 14, got two rides and a choo choo train. Biked about 1000 mikes and camped . I rode a 1980‚Äôs Bridgestone road bike . I bought it used off craigslist. Had three gears infront and six in back. The seat was comfortable but I had to adjust the tilt and the distance between the seat and handlebars. I had racks in front and back. I had new tubes and heavy duty road bike 700c tubes and tires and a new chain. Had it checked out and spiffed up before I left. Years ago I did long trips on a 10 gear road bike. Petaluma ca to big fork Montana and back and a 10 speed from New Jersey to Miami Beach and back . When I led bike trips for American youth hostels we did trips on three speed bikes. As long as the bike fits and is comfy and in good working order, it almost doesn‚Äôt matter. If someone can‚Äôt afford a snazzy bike that is no reason not to go on your bike adventure
data.author: Susan Niman
